results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

This film captures the visit of Australian champion golfer Peter Thomson to the Wangaratta Golf Club in 1956. As shown by the poster in the film, Thomson teaches a golf clinic to an avid crowd. At the time, Thomson had won the British Open twice, and would go on to win it a total of five times - he was the first Australian golfer to win the championship and the only man to have won it in three consecutive years in the twentieth century (1954, 1955 and 1956).

The film shows off the lovely surrounds of the Golf Club set against the backdrop of the town itself and in particular, the backyards of houses. The golfers are particularly smartly dressed in clothes suitable for striding around the course with their golf bags and trolleys, the women in pleated or full mid calf skirts and the men tucking ties into shirts and full 1950s style trousers.

In this film, we can feel the atmosphere of Wangaratta in the post war period - a growing, prosperous community with an increasingly cosmopolitan outlook thanks to an influx of migrants to the area.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title card ‘Wangaratta Golf Club ‘
00:00:25:00 four golfers appraoching a green wearing stylish golfing clothes of the era
00:01:09:00 golfers shaking hands
00:01:38:00 a particularly nice pink hat on a golfer and an example of the 1950s style golf cart
00:02:09:00 more examples of golfing fashion including sun visors
00:03:19:00 a woman carries her cardigan and bag on her golf cart
00:04:02:00 a closer look at a golf bag in a cart
00:04:27:00 post golf drinks at the clubhouse
00:04:51:00 advertising leaflet for ‘Exhibition Golf and Clinic by Peter Thomson (Dual British Open Champion)’, described as the ‘Greatest Golf Day in History’ followed by scenes of the golf clinic in action
00:04:53:00 a woman with a camera taking shots of Thomson as he conducts the golf clinic
00:05:55:00 views of the large crowd at the golf clinic
00:06:30:00 close-up of Thomson’s golfclubs engraved with his name in protective covers with pom poms
00:06:39:00 a man tees off with a cigarette in his mouth
00:07:00:00 the crowd of onlookers surge forward following a player whlist holding up the boundary rope
00:07:44:00 everyone focused on the player as he lines up a shot
00:08:25:00 Thomson giving lessons on how to grip the golf club in the golf clinic
00:09:45:00 close-up of the crowd
00:11:14:00 local golfers say hello to the camera with lovely old houses behind the golf course
00:12:48:00 a golfer in a 1950s style hat likely to be a ‘Stetson’ and his tie tucked into his shirt leans casually on his golfclub before we see him toss his cigarette stub behind him
00:13:07:00 a refreshment tent set up near the golf course clubhouse with people relaxed
00:13:42:00 ladies and beers at the refreshment tent
00:13:50:00 the camera pans an attentative crowd of onlookers
00:14:47:00 the large crowd follow the play under huge lovely trees on the golf course

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film contains great footage of a trip to Japan, including urban scenes, Japanese cars, visits to temples and socialising with Japanese locals.

This film was made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 aeroplanes on the tarmac
00:00:14:00 view from the plane as it takes off, including the Sydney Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge
00:01:32:00 coastline from the plane
00:01:45:00 view from the plane, Bali International Airport Ngurah Rai
00:02:20:00 scenes in Japan
00:03:00:00 feeding the deer, probably at Nara
00:03:30:00 Tōdai-ji, Nara (temple complex)
00:04:05:00 Bishamonten statue, Tōdai-ji, Nara
00:04:45:00 in the forest and visiting temples
00:05:41:00 a cute Japanese toddler in pink overalls
00:07:35:00 driving through city streets, views from the window of a bus
00:08:55:00 groups of Japanese schoolchildren having their photo taken at a temple
00:11:17:00 a fish pond with a waterfall (Ninomaru Garden and pond, Nijo Castle, Kyoto)
00:11:35:00 people viewing didactic map of Nijo Castle complex, Kyoto
00:14:00:00 cable car on a busy city street
00:15:08:00 neon sign ‘Matsushita Electric’
00:17:53:00 orderly city streets filled with traffic
00:20:10:00 View of Mt Fuji
00:20:55:00 close-ups of group of Japanese friends at dinner, all laughing and pulling faces at the camera
00:22:43:00 bright neon billboards at night
00:24:00:00 Coca-Cola billboard
00:25:02:00 view of city buildings from a plane landing
00:26:00:00 views across the harbour of a city (possibly Hong Kong)
00:28:34:00 double decker cable cars covered in advertising

results.title: [Len Moncur Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
This films shows the 1956 Melbourne Olympic Games, including the opening ceremony, athletes competing in events, decorations in the city and the arrival of Prince Philip to close the Olympic Games.

Selected highlights list:
00:03:51:00 Olympic sign featuring torch, ‘1956’ and the rings
00:08:27:00 cyclists on a velodrome
00:09:57:00 some spectacular diving at the Olympic Swimming Stadium
00:11:44:00 torch bearers running with the Olympic torch
00:13:45:00 the Opening Ceremony
00:20:10:00 Ron Clarke running into the stadium
00:21:00:00 Clarke lighting the cauldron
00:25:35:00 television broadcast vans including the Herald Sun, the ABC and GTV9
00:25:49:00 various track and field events
00:33:30:00 athletes walking up through the crowd of spectators
00:35:41:00 newspaper headlines for Betty Cuthbert’s win
00:41:47:00 Flinders Street Station decorated with the Olympic rings and flags
00:49:00:00 licence plate with Olympic rings
00:49:48:00 on the harbour for yachting
00:51:50:00 the arrival of Prince Philip
00:54:30:00 crowds, including people in costume
00:54:50:00 rows of parked 1950s cars
01:00:52:00 athletes sign autographs
01:02:01:00 a fallen cyclist is helped up by two officials
01:04:07:00 country flags lining a boulevard
01:11:12:00 a brass band
01:16:00:00 Olympic rings lit up at night
01:16:35:00 the closing ceremony

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 31]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 88m film.

This film showcases Wilson’s Promontory in Victoria, in particular the coastlines and islands as the filming is done from on board a motorsail boat. Wallace captures the dramatic rocky formations of the shores of the Promontory as well as fishing off the boat and preparing the catch. The fish is likely to be local favourite, ‘King George Whiting’.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:08:00 a woman takes photographs from the deck of a moving ‘motorsail’ boat
00:00:45:00 a mountainous island comes into view followed by views of rocky shorelines and cliffs
00:03:03:00 a boat crosses the water
00:03:18:00 fishing off the back of the moving boat
00:05:35:00 seagulls sitting on the wavy water surface
00:05:51:00 spectacular rocks on the shoreline
00:06:17:00 fish catch in a crate and struggling to remove the fish hook
00:07:10:00 views from the boat looking toward the rocky shoreline
00:08:40:00 lighthouse at South East Point built in 1859
00:10:55:00 waterbirds standing on shoreline rocks
00:11:18:00 gutting and filleting fish on old wooden crates in the stern of the boat
00:11:26:00 a speed boat passes by
00:12:11:00 pier and fishing

00:00:45:00 a mountainous island comes into view followed by views of rocky shorelines and cliffs
00:03:03:00 a boat crosses the water
00:03:18:00 fishing off the back of the moving boat
00:05:35:00 seagulls sitting on the wavy water surface
00:05:51:00 spectacular rocks on the shoreline
00:06:17:00 fish catch in a crate and struggling to remove the fish hook
00:07:10:00 views from the boat looking toward the rocky shoreline
00:08:40:00 lighthouse at South East Point built in 1859
00:10:55:00 waterbirds standing on shoreline rocks
00:11:18:00 gutting and filleting fish on old wooden crates in the stern of the boat
00:11:26:00 a speed boat passes by
00:12:11:00 pier and fishing
description_for_label:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 88m film.

This film showcases Wilson’s Promontory in Victoria, in particular the coastlines and islands as the filming is done from on board a motorsail boat. Wallace captures the dramatic rocky formations of the shores of the Promontory as well as fishing off the boat and preparing the catch. The fish is likely to be local favourite, ‘King George Whiting’.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 166]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This is a particularly lovely colour film comprising scenes from Ron and Jess Gadsden’s early life when their children were small, in 1952. They are enjoying life at home (Lansell Rd, Toorak in Melbourne), sitting in the sun with the children, on the beach at Frankston on the Mornington Peninsula and a birthday for one of the girls back at Lansell Rd.

The second half of the film shows school sports at the Geelong Grammar Toorak Campus, ‘Glamorgan’, which Ron films through a round frame.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:59:00 Jess Gadsden teaches one of her children to swim in shallows at Frankston beach
00:01:59:00 view of Frankston bay with cliff top houses in the background
00:02:20:00 filmmaker Ron playing in water with his children
00:03:12:00 Jess preparing lunch on a small plate sitting on the beach
00:04:14:00 birthday party at Jess and Ron Gadsden’s home, with family and pony rides
00:06:42:00 sports day for primary school children with onlooking parents and teachers guiding the proceedings

results.title: Sony Handycam DCR-SX65
results.brief_description: The Sony Handycam DCR-SX65 debuted in 1985 and while other models from the era have been discontinued, it’s been made in various formats ever since. Home videos might have been their original purpose, but camcorders like this have captured footage that has social and political ramifications.

constellations_primary.name: A handheld aesthetic
constellations_primary.description: Looking at the use of handycams and other consumer level devices in moving image works.

results.description: The Sony Handycam DCR-SX65 is what it says: it’s a handy camera. Debuting on the market in 1985, its name came from its compact size that allowed it to fit in the user’s hand and capture their everyday lives more easily. While other models from this era have been discontinued, the Sony Handycam DCR-SX65’s popularity has seen it made in various formats ever since. Home videos might have been their original purpose, but their cost and convivence meant camcorders like this have been used to capture amateur footage that has social and political ramifications all around the world.

results.title: Hi 5: It's a Hi 5 Christmas
results.creator_credit: Gary Newhnam, Ian Munro, Russell Burton, Alisa Smeaton, Kids Like Us and Nine Films and Television
results.brief_description: A Hi5 Christmas extravaganza! The usual features of a Hi5 television program with the bonus of a live Christmas concert performed in front of an audience at the Sidney Myer Music Bowl in Melbourne. Can be viewed by pressing Play or by selecting the profiles for each group member: Charli, Nathan, Kathleen, Tim or Kellie. Includes “Body move”, “Shapes in space”, “Puzzles and patterns”, “Making music” and “Word play”. Suitable for very young children or early primary school age. Created by Helena Harris and Posie Graeme-Evans.

holdings.name: DVD; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: What women want
results.creator_credit: Nancy Meyers, Bruce Davey, Gina Matthews, Matt Williams, Susan Cartonis, Centropolis Effects, ICON, Paramount Pictures and Wind Dancer Productions
results.brief_description: Nick Marshall (Mel Gibson) is a real ladies man. Raised by his mother, a Las Vegas showgirl, he has a somewhat distorted perception of what women really want, and an enormous ego. When he is passed over for an executive position in the advertising agency for a woman his chauvinistic attitude worsens. A freak accident while trying to brainstorm ideas for a new advertising campaign, leaves Nick with the ability to hear what women think. Amazed by his new talent Nick seeks the help of a therapist (Bette Midler) who suggests he think of it as a gift and not a curse, and to use this to his advantage. Nick sets his sights on Darcy McGuire (Helen Hunt), the new creative director in the agency. At first his plan works, and he undermines Darcy at every opportunity, until he realises Darcy has feelings for him, and that he feels the same way about her. Cast also includes Marisa Tomei, Mark Feurstein, Lauren Holly, Valerie Perrine, Delta Bourke and Alan Alda
